We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators has an initial object, which is the space of complex-valued functions on the real line. This provides a categorical foundation for quantum theory in terms of the language and methods of category theory.

The origin of parasitism is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. Here, we show that the Myxozoa, a group of microscopic parasites, are cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids. This finding has important implications for the origin of parasitism, as well as for the evolution of the cnidarian body plan.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 70% to meet this demand. This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which is a key adaptation strategy to reduce the impact of climate change on maize production.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven species of African LMH, and found that the degree of overlap in diet composition was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than within either the grazing or browsing guilds. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results have implications for understanding the role of LMH in the functioning of African savanna ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, but most expect to remain in business for at least 3 mo. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. The majority of businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. The cosmic ray exposure ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains from the Murchison CM2 meteorite are presented. The grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the sun was not the primary source of the cosmogenic nuclides in the grains. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to the mother is a strong driver of reproductive output, and that this effect is not limited to the evolution of domestication. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of multiple system atrophy, a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder, and opens the door for further studies in this model and in patients.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, inflammation, and hemostasis. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is organized in a way that allows for rapid communication between all cells in the network. This organization is important for the endothelium to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for the development of new therapies for cardiovascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health agencies and researchers. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and practitioners in the public health community. The data are available at https://covidcast.org. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the pore of K+ channels, and it is the site of ion conduction. Inactivation of K+ channels is a fundamental process that is involved in the regulation of many physiological processes. We have identified a key residue that is involved in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. This allosteric communication is crucial for the proper functioning of K+ channels.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex community of microorganisms that is essential for the health of the animal and the health of the ecosystem. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the animal is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is influenced by the diet of the animal. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a group of microorganisms that are rarely studied, synthesize natural products that could be used as therapeutics. This study provides a foundation for the study of the role of anaerobic fungi in the health of herbivores and the potential for the discovery of new natural products.

Anxiety is a common feature of many psychiatric disorders, and the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens is known to be altered in anxiety disorders. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and that the nucleus accumbens is involved in the establishment of social hierarchy. We further demonstrate that the energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens is critical for the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals and that this is mediated by the modulation of mitochondrial function. Our findings highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens for social behavior and point to the energy metabolism in this brain region as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The ability to design and fabricate structures with desired mechanical responses is of great importance for the development of various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and the design of a specific structure are often limited to the realization of a specific response. Here, we propose a synthesis and fabrication strategy to design and fabricate structures with multiple material phases, which are optimally synthesized to realize any desired response. The structures are digitally synthesized and then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and fabrication of mechanical devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in the human body. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal stages of human development and is down-regulated in the adult. We show that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells, resulting in a more fetal-like pattern of hemoglobin expression. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is required for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that this resistance is mediated by mTORC1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for ferroptosis induction in cancer cells, and that this activity is mediated by monounsaturated fatty acids. These findings suggest that ferroptosis induction may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment in patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular medicine. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism that involves the N terminus of the STIM protein. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but that the decline of older forests accelerated. This finding is important because the NWFP was based on the assumption that the conservation of older forests would reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results suggest that the NWFP needs to be strengthened to halt the decline of older forests and the associated bird populations.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is expected to be useful for the design of new antibiotics against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. (Show more)

We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems. The evolution of Lake Malawi, one of the world’s largest lakes, and its fish fauna, one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems, is intimately linked to the climate history of the region. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi. The record shows that the evolution of the lake and its fish fauna was influenced by a combination of large-scale climate variability and local forcing, including the evolution of the climate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition.

This study shows that exposure to electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. This is the first study to show that exposure to electronic devices can cause a delay in the circadian clock, suppress melatonin, and reduce the quality of sleep. This study has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The cause of the YD cooling is still debated. One of the proposed causes is the impact of a bolide. We show that the osmium isotopic composition of the bolide material is consistent with the YD cooling.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, and that its expression in the thymus is essential for the development of Treg cells.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of genes from 521 species, and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved the evolutionary history of beetles, revealed that the origin of beetles and plants coincided, and showed that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers were key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These results suggest that beetles diversified in response to the evolution of novel genes in plants, and that beetle diversity may be limited by the loss of these genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to optimize the CDR sequences of an antibody to improve its binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

We show that the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We conducted a large-scale experiment in which participants learned from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. We found that larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This is important because it has implications for the evolution of technology in general, and for the evolution of culture in particular.

The role of apolipoprotein E (APOE) in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is well established. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is highly polymorphic. APOE4 is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD, and APOE2 is associated with a decreased risk for AD. However, the mechanisms underlying the effect of APOE on AD risk are not fully understood. Here, we show that APOE is important for the regulation of the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a critical process in normal brain function and is essential for normal AD brain. Our results suggest that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhance their vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis needs to be tested in future studies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the rapid solidification of the core material, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, which is different from the conventional one-step nucleation scenario. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results are important for understanding the formation of the inner core and the evolution of the Earth. They also provide a new perspective for the study of the solidification process of metals. Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of it is a key focus of neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict the contents of the human brain while doing so. This suggests that the brain’s processing of language is fundamentally predictive in nature.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been difficult to use in scientific computing. We show that this difficulty is due to the instability of DL, which is a consequence of the optimization methods used to train the networks. We prove that this instability can be eliminated by using a different optimization method, and we demonstrate that this method is both fast and accurate. Our results have implications for the use of DL in scientific computing, and they also have implications for the theory of neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. This paper discusses the classic experiment that is the basis for much of this research. It shows that the experiment’s design is flawed in a way that has been overlooked in the literature. The paper concludes with a discussion of the implications of this case study for the study of human behavior.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it continues to be a major health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogenicity of the uncultured Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which is the cause of the chronic, progressive, and often fatal lepromatous form of leprosy, has been unclear. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions, despite their ancient separation. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of leprosy and its pathogens. (PsycINFO Database Record

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a careful analysis of the quasiparticles’ spectrum and of the entanglement dynamics in the steady state. Our result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics, and it opens the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is critical to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, COVI-VAC, which is currently in phase I clinical trials. The vaccine is temperature sensitive, grows robustly at the permissive temperature, and is highly protective in a relevant hamster model.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague is still debated, with rodents and fleas being the most common hypotheses. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas, were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results are based on a mathematical model, which can be used to study the role of vectors in the spread of infectious diseases in the past and in the present.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important factors in the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain size as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive capacity is not free of bias. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is not only characterized by the increase in brain size but also by the increase in the number of neurons. This study also shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of cognitive capacity.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the role of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the cytoskeletal elements that are responsible for many cellular processes. They are dynamic structures that can be disassembled and reassembled, and this process is critical for many cellular processes. The proteins that are responsible for this process are the actin depolymerizing factors (ADF)/cofilins. We show that these proteins are able to sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is critical for many cellular processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater desire for food and food-related behavior. These findings suggest that the effects of fructose on feeding behavior may be greater than previously thought.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we show that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent admixture of Malagasy individuals with both Southeast Asians and Africans. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the genetic structure is also influenced by geography. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar, and for the development of genomic tools for the study of human populations. They also provide a framework for the study of the genetic diversity of the Indian Ocean islands.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, with more than 800,000 people participating, and it is the first to show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This work suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ negative experiences can be harmful.

The presence of mRNA modifications has been known for decades to influence the structure and function of messenger RNAs. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis has been less well studied. Here, we show that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis.

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and well-being, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of aquatic life is a major driver of the size of mammals, but the extent to which this is due to differences in the scaling of energy intake and energy cost with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms has not been tested quantitatively. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of 37 °C has been a source of speculation about the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth. Our results show that the mouse airway epithelium, which is the primary site of rhinovirus infection in humans, exhibits a temperature-dependent growth phenotype, which is dependent on the antiviral defense response of the infected cells.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This mechanosensory system requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pili retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model of surface sensing may be common to other bacteria and may be important for understanding the evolution of sensing systems in bacteria. It also provides a mechanism for how bacteria can sense the mechanical properties of their environment, which is important for understanding the role of bacteria in health and disease. (Show more)

The presence of pesticides in surface water is a global concern. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in the environment is a major concern for the long-term sustainability of the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood and lymph nodes of free-living white-tailed deer, and the detection of multiple human and deer lineages of the virus in the same geographic region. These findings have important implications for the ecology of the virus, and for the development of a One Health approach to the management of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a chronic, progressive, and incurable neurodegenerative disorder, which is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. The exact cause of AD is unknown, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that they are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons, which is a critical step in the development of AD.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. Our faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, provides the earliest secure evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens in the world. This finding is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of the domestic chicken and its integration into the economy.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. This work shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps, the first of which is a native-like intermediate that is a step on the folding pathway and that is a target for mutations that slow folding.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are abundant in response to stress, have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing those caps, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing stress, prefers to remove the monophosphorylated RNA as a prelude to degradation of the entire RNA. This unexpected mechanism of decapping could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanisms involved in the dysfunction of the immune system are still not fully understood. We demonstrated that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also showed that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all living organisms. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in the electronics industry. However, diamond is brittle and can break into pieces under mechanical stress. Here, we show that diamond can be made to behave like a metal, with a zero bandgap, by applying a large enough strain. This opens up many possibilities for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. This work provides a structural and functional characterization of a unique peptide, which is a member of the highly diverse NCR peptide family. The antifungal activity of this peptide is due to its ability to bind to fungal cell walls and disrupt the integrity of the plasma membrane. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is critical to reproductive success. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm, and that these contributions support the viability of sperm during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches A1 and/or GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD mutations. The results are important for understanding the role of force in the regulation of VWF binding to platelets. They also provide a model for the regulation of other proteins in the blood clotting system. The model is relevant to the understanding of the effects of force on the blood clotting system in the body and on the effects of drugs that affect the system. The model may also be relevant to the understanding of the effects of force on other proteins in the cell.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the role of viruses in human health has only recently been explored. This study provides a comprehensive resource for human-associated viruses, and the results from this resource are used to identify associations between viruses and a variety of diseases. This resource will be useful to researchers studying the role of viruses in human health, and will be a valuable addition to the growing field of human microbiome research.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. This is due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic record, the effects of diagenesis and metamorphism, and the depositional environment. We here present a method for determining the temperature of Earth’s surface in the past based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are also the targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their gating mechanisms: voltage-gated channels, ligand-gated channels, and calcium-gated channels. The gating mechanisms of K+ channels are of particular interest because they are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are also the targets of drugs.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. One of the major barriers to the development of new therapies is our limited understanding of the mechanisms of parasite invasion of the red blood cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, which may be a critical step in the invasion process. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical force, but rather a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including in electronics, optics, and quantum technologies. However, it is brittle and can break into pieces under mechanical stress. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be reduced to zero, without breaking the rules of physics. This opens up new possibilities for the design of diamond-based devices and materials.

In this study, we show that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our results provide insights into the role of humidity in the pathogenesis of influenza infection and may help to develop strategies to reduce the severity of influenza-associated respiratory diseases. The brain is thought to build its representation of a sentence by first constructing a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains largely unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be a key to understanding the brain’s efficient representation of the complex structures of natural language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development, and its regulation is of great interest in the context of cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is an important finding in the context of the redundancy of the two forms of Axin in the canonical Wnt pathway.
This study provides a detailed description of the brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

The ability of plants to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in their rhizosphere is a fundamental process in nature, but it is also a key component of the sustainable delivery of nitrogen in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows us to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere of plants. This system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere of plants, and it can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the rhizosphere of plants.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Data from monitoring records and community surveys provide evidence about how the program may affect forest outcomes. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be applied to other tropical forests.

The spider is a model organism for studying the evolution of sensory systems, and in particular, the evolution of hearing. Here, we show that the spider’s hearing is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to be a global health crisis, with the need for a safe and effective vaccine for all countries. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response in mice. This protein can be used to construct a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine, which can be produced at a high yield and is expected to be cost-effective. This engineered RBD protein can also be used to construct a vaccine that can protect against variants of concern.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of human ALK, DrLtk, is a ligand for the zebrafish ALKALs. This finding is of general interest for the understanding of the function of ALK/LTK family receptors in development and disease.

The emergence of plague is one of the most dramatic events in human history, and the pathogen’s impact on human populations has been devastating. However, the timing of its emergence and its early evolution remain poorly understood. We present a large dataset of Yersinia pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during its formative years. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a single, local lineage but rather a panmictic population that spread across Eurasia over millennia. This study provides a unique perspective on the early evolution of plague and its relationship with its host. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The management of agricultural lands has been shown to be a major driver of the global C cycle. In this study, we show that the management of annual cropping systems on a North American Mollisol can be used to increase soil C storage. We show that the use of cover crops, the inclusion of legumes in the crop rotation, and the integration of livestock into the cropping system can increase soil C storage. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in the fight against climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a first step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from wildlife to humans.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s quality, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction.

We present a study of the genetic structure of the population in southern Germany during the Early Middle Ages. Our results indicate that the genetic structure of the population in this region was strongly shaped by geography, but also that the genetic landscape was highly heterogeneous, with a large number of individuals having ancestry from outside the region. This is in contrast to the picture that has emerged from genetic studies of prehistoric populations, which have indicated at least two major waves of immigration from outside Europe. Our results suggest that the genetic landscape of Europe was shaped by a complex interplay of migration and genetic drift, and that this process may have contributed to the genetic diversity of the modern European population.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results show that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5 are opposite to each other. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. This study provides insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and the origin of bat coronaviruses to humans. It also suggests that bat coronaviruses with the capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission pose a threat to human health. (Show more)

This study demonstrates the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya, which was detected before the national outbreak. Our results highlight the importance of mNGS as a pathogen surveillance tool in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS-based pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires the concerted action of multiple proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the replication of the lagging strand is pol δ, which is responsible for synthesizing the Okazaki fragments. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the mechanism of human lagging strand replication. It also provides a framework for understanding the role of pol δ in the repair of DNA lesions. This study will be of interest to the community of researchers working on the replication of the lagging strand and the repair of DNA lesions.

The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step forward in the quest to understand the origin of life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities.
The clinical efficacy of tocilizumab in severe and critical COVID-19 patients was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a metal that can be toxic to cells. In this study, we report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This discovery has implications for the role of natural products in fungal interactions with other microbes, and it suggests that the role of natural products in metal homeostasis may be more widespread than previously thought.

The presence of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery, as it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph, which is not stable at the temperatures of the present day surface of Mars. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous material is a mixture of precipitated silica, diagenesis products, and/or fracture/vein fill. The source of the tridymite, amorphous silica, and other minerals is from the wall/rim/central peak region of Gale crater.

Frost events are a major cause of crop and forest losses, but the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are also changing in response. Our results have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is unclear. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease and screen for therapeutics. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new therapies.

The gut microbiota of ticks is critical for the acquisition of pathogens, and the composition of the microbiota is influenced by the tick’s environment. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein in the tick, which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. We demonstrate that the protein binds to the bacterial cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the tick microbiota and suggest that targeting the tick microbiota may be a potential strategy for controlling tick-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. However, the study of the early evolution of the avian tail is limited due to the lack of fossils. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery adds important information about the origin of the short tail in birds.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere is increasing with tropospheric temperature, implying that the water vapor in the stratosphere is playing a role in the climate system. This is a new result, and it has important implications for the climate sensitivity of the Earth system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for humans to appreciate the beauty of nature. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein binds biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of nature. This discovery is important because it shows that the color of animals can be changed by a protein, and it also shows that the color of animals can be changed by a protein that binds a molecule that is responsible for the green color of nature. Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is regulated by HIFs and ALKBH5, and is lost upon mutation of the methylated residue. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in hypoxic tumors may contribute to the emergence of CSCs.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the extraction of protein from the parchment surface using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction and its causes are critical to understanding the evolution of life on Earth.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and inflammation. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. The structure of the spike glycoprotein is a complex of high-risk variants, which are associated with increased transmissibility. The structure of the spike glycoprotein provides a basis for understanding the mechanism of action of the vaccine and antiviral drugs.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 and its consequences. (PsycINFO Database Record

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. This work is a step forward in the understanding of the chemistry of matter under pressure. It is also a step forward in the prediction of the chemistry of matter under pressure. This work is a step forward in the prediction of the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We show that human demography, as opposed to climate, is the dominant driver of fire activity in the 20th and 21st centuries. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has offset some of the warming caused by human emissions. However, the risk of more extreme fires in the future means that climate change may still be the dominant driver of fire activity. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate change on fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms that regulate the delivery of nutrients to the symbionts of animals are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel fashion. This glycan is released from the immune cells of the host only at night, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation. The catabolism of this glycan by the symbionts is also required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts and enhances their luminescence. Our results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a general mechanism for regulating the stability of animal-associated microbiomes. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. This method is based on a combination of two recent advances in machine learning: topic modeling and word embedding. Our method is flexible and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and medical records. We believe that this approach will be useful to many researchers and practitioners.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its geographic spread. (Less)

Asteroids are a common component of the marine ecosystem, but in recent years, they have been the focus of a devastating disease that has led to the mass mortality of populations on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by the sea star. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a heterogeneous disease with a poor prognosis. We show that a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL1RAP receptor is effective in xenograft models of human AML. This antibody is effective in both the absence and presence of effector cells, suggesting that it can achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. Furthermore, we show that the antibody can also block IL-1 signaling, suggesting that it can be used to treat AML by blocking the IL-1 pathway. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we show that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several waves, with a recent admixture of Malagasy individuals with both Southeast Asians and Africans. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not a homogeneous process, and that the genetic structure is also influenced by geography. These results have important implications for the understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar, and for the interpretation of the genetic diversity of the island. They also have implications for the interpretation of the genetic diversity of the Indian Ocean islands, and for the understanding of the genetic diversity of the African continent. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.”
