The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to optimize the CDR sequences of an antibody to improve its binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical to monitor crop conditions and predict crop yields. However, the information they provide is often difficult to access and use. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey of the US Department of Agriculture can be used to derive a continuous, probabilistic measure of crop status that is robust to changes in the number of surveyors and the number of crops assessed. This allows for the construction of a Crop Condition Index that can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict crop yields earlier and more accurately than official forecasts released midseason. The method can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the impact of climate change on crop conditions. The results are relevant to farmers, policy makers, and researchers.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements from 27 temperature manipulation experiments. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration is not increasing with warming in most biomes, contrary to the results from single-site studies. This suggests that the global warming signal in soil respiration may be masked by the effects of climate variability, and that the response of soil respiration to warming may be highly variable across the globe.

The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key factor in the study of the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the origin of life, is reflected in the molecular evolution of the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was caused by a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. However, the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the drought risk in SSA is difficult to quantify, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the field of materials science. The discovery of the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, has been a major advance in the history of the world. The two discoveries are linked by the discovery of a new composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first known anthropogenic material to contain a quasicrystal.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy that is stored in the form of biomass. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is achieved by the capture of light by the pigments chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll, and the conversion of this energy to chemical energy. The pigments are modified tetrapyrroles, and the formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the so-called “cyclium,” is the most important reaction in this process.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the pathogenesis of EAE. In this study, we have identified the roles of neuroinflammation-associated kinase, ASK1, in the development of EAE. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of EAE. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a genetic basis, and the identification of the causal genes is a major challenge. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and may facilitate the development of Drosophila as a model system for autism research. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” (PsycINFO Database Record

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the immune system, and is also involved in a variety of other cellular processes. In this study, we identify mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and in the CRAC channel activator ORAI1 that lead to a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, that are reminiscent of Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain in a model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein, MTX, that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that MTX is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit for the synthesis of the bases of DNA and RNA. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is essential for the supply of the one-carbon unit to cancer cells. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell cancers. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer, but is toxic to B-cell cancers. Thus, the one-carbon unit is a metabolic target for cancer therapy. This work provides a new strategy for the treatment of cancer.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in the inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that the presence of these proteins is not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the unique properties of the protein, such as their propensity to form amyloid fibrils, or the cellular environment, such as the presence of reactive oxygen species. This metastable state may be a common feature of proteins that are prone to aggregation in neurodegenerative disorders. Thus, the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a marker for a more general mechanism of disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The study of the early evolution of angiosperms is hampered by a lack of material and a lack of knowledge of the material that is available. This study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous of Spain, is a step forward in the understanding of the early evolution of angiosperms.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of the history of life on Earth. However, the study of virus evolution has been hampered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that the evolution of viruses is not as fast as previously thought. This is important for understanding the evolution of viruses in the context of the origin of life. View Full-Text

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and important indicators of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest time period for which we have a consistent record of satellite altimeter measurements. The results are in agreement with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the causes of the increase in pain are not well understood. We show that the increase in pain is not due to the aging of the population, but rather to the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical piece of information for understanding enzyme function. However, the structure of this complex is difficult to obtain because of the dynamic nature of the enzyme active site. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex, and how this structure can be used to understand the reaction pathway of the enzyme.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral RNA synthesis, which has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection is effective in preventing and treating the disease, respectively. The data support the development of a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS, and also suggest that it may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing outbreak.

The provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, is a critical event in the life cycle of the mutualism between squid and its light-producing symbiont. We show that this glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of chitin is specifically required for the periodic acidification of the squid’s symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbionts. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiosis may be a common feature of animal–microbe interactions.

This research shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved through a simple, scalable intervention. The results have implications for the way we think about and intervene in the school–prison pipeline.

Alkylated DNA lesions are ubiquitous in all living organisms. However, the molecular mechanisms of how alkylation-induced DNA lesions affect the efficiency and accuracy of transcription remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylation-induced DNA lesions on transcription. We found that the presence of alkylation-induced DNA lesions can lead to transcriptional stalling, which is dependent on the type of alkylation-induced DNA lesions. Furthermore, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, which is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the effects of alkylation-induced DNA lesions on transcription. This work also provides a better understanding of the effects of alkylation-induced DNA lesions on transcription, which is essential for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We show that the sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection of other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. (Show more)

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40%. This is a large effect, and it is achieved with a simple change to the catering system. The results are robust to a range of different analyses and are consistent with the idea that increasing the proportion of vegetarian options available in the environment in which people make decisions can lead to more people choosing vegetarian options. This has important implications for the food system, as well as for the design of interventions to promote sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we show that the surfaceome is dramatically remodeled in a cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and that this remodeling is driven by the oncogene itself, and is coordinated by a set of common themes. We complement the surfaceome data with glycoproteomics, and find that the oncogenes induce a large number of changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step in understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer.

In response to the coronavirus pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein is presented. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a molecular understanding of the unique features of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and may lead to the development of new antiviral therapies.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of the water channel AQP4 and the endothelin receptor ET-1, which in turn leads to edema. These findings may help to understand the pathophysiology of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We live in an era of big data. This is a good thing, because big data allow us to study many more phenomena than in the past. However, big data also present new challenges, because we need to be more selective in the inferences that we draw from the data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. These methods can help us to be more selective in our data analysis. This will be important as we collect and analyze even bigger data sets in the future.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 in the generation of ECs may be applicable to the generation of ECs for the regeneration of the liver and other organs.

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the biology of these two receptors, which are involved in a variety of human cancers. We also report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the RTKs, which is involved in the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment cells.

In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency causes glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS. Moreover, we found that STING is required for the expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, which is essential for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide a new insight into the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis, and suggest that STING might be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but also complicates the packaging of the genome into the viral particles. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the packaging of the viral genome is a complex process that involves a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of this network among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and might be useful for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades. This paper provides a quantitative assessment of the role of human activities in increasing the extent of wildfire, and the implications of this increase for the future of wildfire in the United States.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic and social outcomes of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and the collapse of the coral reef. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier between the host and the environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to dysbiosis of the microbiome and a loss of host–microbe homeostasis. We show that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn stimulates tumor growth. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the crosstalk between tumors and the microbiome, and it may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to treatment. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression correlates with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Furthermore, treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab reduced the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice, and improved the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a matter of debate. Here, we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption, which is the first of a series of volcanic eruptions that continued for 192 y. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly contributed to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. Our results reveal that freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the world’s poor, and that the most productive rivers are also the most threatened by overfishing and other human impacts. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries management is needed to protect biodiversity and food security. This analysis highlights the importance of freshwater fisheries for the world’s poor and undernourished, and the need to protect these critical ecosystems.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are responsible for the high capacity and low operating potential. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of aqueous batteries. View Full-Text

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of genes involved in regeneration, and it may also lead to the development of new regenerative therapies.

We describe a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which is the closest living relative of humans. Our results show that the distribution of recombination rates is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the patterns of recombination in these three very different organisms are related.

The resting state of the brain is a complex phenomenon, which is difficult to study because of the small fraction of total neuronal activity that is represented in the fMRI signal. Here, we show that the dominant component of metabolic activity in the resting state of the human brain is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant component of metabolic activity was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. In healthy subjects and early PD patients, the dominant metabolic RSN was deactivating during rest, whereas in advanced PD this pattern was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

We report the discovery of a 5′ cap structure in yeast mRNAs that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on mRNAs that are 5′ end-processed. The presence of this cap suggests that NAD+ may play a role in modulating the stability and translation of specific classes of mRNA in yeast.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study.

This study provides a mechanism for the role of FSIP1 in the sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer cells to chemotherapy drugs. This study may aid in the design of new therapies for triple-negative breast cancer. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of the disease and in the regulation of the behavior of the patient. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a fundamental process in nature, and the ability to control the production of these compounds is of great interest to the food industry. In this study, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a precursor to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss, and because the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is central to understanding the functioning of ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of climate change on the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from freely moving mice in an open field, and we found that grid cells, which are essential for the formation of a spatial map, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These findings suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network from those of border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. This organization may be important for the formation of a robust spatial map. Our results have implications for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. (PsycINFO Database Record

Dodder is a root- and leafless plant that parasitizes a large number of autotrophic plant species. The dodder plant does not synthesize its own food, but instead depends on its host plant for its nutrition. The dodder plant is able to synchronize its flowering with the flowering of its host plant. This study shows that the flowering of the host plant is required for the flowering of the dodder plant. This is an example of how parasites may synchronize their reproduction with that of their hosts, which may be an important factor for the fitness of both the host and the parasite.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro system, which project to the striatum to form the classic nigrostriatal pathway, receive input from the striosome, a newly discovered subcompartment of the dopamine neuron, and project to the striatum as part of the classic pathway. We also show that the dopamine neurons receive input from other neurons in the nigro system and project to other regions of the brain, including those that are related to mood and motivation. Thus, the dopamine neurons of the nigro system likely form a loop that is critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by both people and third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust their activity to meet the changing demands of the body. This is achieved by integrating information from the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. Stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ stores and the plasma membrane. Here, we show that STIM1 is a key regulator of SAN automaticity.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to enhance plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies for rice. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex mixture of lipids that are involved in a variety of cellular processes. The lipidome of macrophages is also involved in the regulation of macrophage function. In this study, we show that tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor of nitric oxide synthesis, is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids, which are a class of lipids that are involved in the regulation of macrophage function. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid metabolism are involved in the regulation of the macrophage immune response.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

This work is focused on the delivery of biomolecules to plants, which is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. We show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants, which is a major physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules across the cell wall of plants depends on the geometry of the DNA nanostructures. This work is expected to be useful for the plant biology community and also for the development of new technologies for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this study shows that the nutrient inputs from small streams can be significant and can have a disproportionate impact on coastal ecosystems. Our results show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake, but that the nutrient loads from small streams are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that the nearshore zone of these lakes may be more vulnerable to eutrophication from small streams than previously thought. Our findings highlight the importance of managing nutrient inputs from all watersheds, large and small, to protect the health of valuable coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong environmental forcing. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a driven quantum system, and we discuss the implications of our results for the study of the dynamics of complex networks of interacting agents.

This study provides a detailed description of the effects of an antibody against the NMDA receptor on the brain’s electrical activity. The results are important because they provide a mechanistic understanding of the relationship between the antibody and the brain’s electrical activity, which is the basis for the development of new therapies. The results also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. Here, we present an integrated proxy (C and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over ∼300 kyr and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduces deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that most of the remaining forest is degraded. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the desired effect of reducing deforestation in the tropics.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with polygenic sex determination, multiple alleles interact to produce the sex of an individual. Here we show that the interaction of multiple alleles can produce a modular effect on secondary sexual characteristics, resulting in a variety of phenotypes that are linked to the sex of an individual. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE, respectively. The photoreceptor-generated ROS are quenched by the RPE, but the RPE is challenged by the RPE-generated ROS, which are not quenched. We show that the levels of iron (Fe) in the retina impact the balance between the generation and degradation of the RPE-generated ROS.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the functioning of food webs. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of the feeding strategies of the pelagic cnidarian siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their specialized feeding apparatus, and that these changes are not only local but also extend to the rest of the organism. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of the most extreme cases of predator specialization.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the timing of the evolution of the modern human hand and the emergence of the human capacity for tool use. It also provides a unique window into the evolution of the human hand in Africa, a region of the world where the fossil record is particularly rich. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is a key metabolic enzyme that converts serine to glycine. We have shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We have also shown that the inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of lymphoma cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells that can be targeted therapeutically. This work has implications for the treatment of lymphoma, and for the development of new therapeutics for cancer in general.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this is likely to be the result of a reduction in the availability of fruits and vegetables. This study also shows that the presence of forests can lead to an increase in the consumption of fruits and vegetables, and thus to an increase in the vitamin A content of diets. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also provides evidence that the use of causal inference methods can be used to test hypotheses about the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This study is an example of how the use of causal inference methods can lead to the development of new insights into the effects of environmental change on people’s lives.

Modern agriculture is the most productive and efficient food production system in history, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. We show that the increase in farm machinery capacity has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with potential loss of soil productivity. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles.
